Specific Details: Convergence/Farm Entitlements
Subject Matter: Convergence/Farm Entitlements
Intended Results: To explain that Convergence was introduced as part of the 2013 CAP reform with the objective of flattening per hectare payments across each Member State in the EU. Between 2015-2019 Ireland undertook partial convergence bringing each farmer's per hectare payment up to at least 60% of the national average.::To highlight that in the lead up to last week's Trilogues in Brussels, the European Commission and the EU Council of Agriculture Ministers had proposed 75% internal convergence to be achieved by the end of the next programme (2027), while the European Parliament has sought 100% convergence. More recently, the Portuguese Presidency proposed 85% convergence in an effort to reach an agreement.  We understand no agreement on this yet.::To demonstrate that farmers were placed on one of three convergence paths which resulted in their individual entitlement values increasing, deceasing or remaining unchanged.::To demonstrate the number of farmers on each of the convergence paths 2015 to 2019 and the percentage change to the average entitlement value on a per county basis as a result of convergence.  In every county there are farmers that are contributing, receiving or are unchanged by convergence.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Elaine Farrell, Director of Governance & Oireachtas Engagement

Specific Details: The National Reserve Scheme
Subject Matter: The National Reserve Scheme
Intended Results: To outline the National Reserve and entitlements where there is a sale of entitlements currently held and a subsequent acquisition of entitlements from the National Reserve for the successor::- You must be able to demonstrate that there was no intent to artificially create conditions to benefit under a scheme.::- Ireland is obliged to implement EU funded schemes under the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) in line with EU regulations governing the operation of the schemes. In this regard, the regulatory provision governing circumvention is set out in EU Regulation 2116/2021 in Article 62 - Circumvention Clause.::- Without prejudice to specific provisions of Union law, Member State shall take effective and proportionate measures to avoid provisions of Union law to be circumvented and ensure, in particular, that no advantage provided for under agricultural legislation is granted in favour of a natural or legal person in respect of whom it is established that the conditions required for obtaining such advantages were created artificially, contrary to the objectives of that legislation.y::- In order to comply with this Regulatory requirement, the Department is obliged to highlight this provision to prospective scheme applicants. With regard to the National Reserve, the Terms and Conditions refer to the Circumvention clause and provide and example of circumvention as the removal of existing entitlements from land for the purpose of creating 'naked land' upon which a National Reserve allocation may be made.::The Department's concern is cases where there is a clear and obvious attempt to artificially create conditions required to obtain advantage under schemes. Payment entitlements are not attached to land and the owner of the entitlements has the option to transfer the entitlements by methods including sale or lease in line with normal business decisions regarding the farming enterprise and the future of the holding or the individual.::The Department cannot give pre-approval for an application or for the inclusion of particular land as part of an application. Each application must be considered in its entirety when it has been submitted following the scheme closing date, including the land submitted in support of the application.::However, all applications will also be considered in the context of the intention of the support measure, which is generational renewal in the case of the National Reserve, and the steps required to facilitate generational renewal within the holding. Where a case is found to be outside the spirit and intention of the support measure the Department's concern will be that a clear and obvious attempt has been made to artificially create the conditions to benefit.::. A genuine application submitted in keeping with the spirit and intention of the scheme is the basis on which the Department seeks to approve support measures for young farmers and new entrants. The Department may require further information in relation to an application when the applications are being processed and, in this regard, you should satisfy yourself that the application is in compliance with the objectives, and the Terms and Conditions, of the scheme.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Shane Whelan IFA Senior Policy Executive, Rachel Moloney IFA Policy Executive
